title: Crankcases - Assembly

body.body: Use high flashpoint solvent to clean the crankcase mating faces. Wipe the surfaces clean with a lint-free cloth.
Fit the gearbox shafts (if removed), ensuring the locating ring and dowels on the output shaft bearings are positioned correctly in the crankcase.
Ensure that the transmission is in neutral.
Ensure that the three locating dowels are in position in the upper crankcase.
Apply a thin bead of silicone sealer (at the factory,
is used) to the lower crankcase mating faces.
Do not use excessive amounts of sealer. The extra sealer may become dislodged and could block the oil passages in the crankcases causing severe engine damage.
If removed, insert the three piston cooling jets into the main bearing housings in the upper crankcase.
Ensure the three piston cooling jets are installed. If the piston cooling jets are omitted, oil pressure will be reduced. Running the engine with low oil pressure will cause severe engine damage.

The piston cooling jet for number three cylinder is longer and has a larger diameter drilling than the piston cooling jets for number one and two cylinders. It can also be identified by its smaller outside diameter and a groove around its circumference. Piston cooling jets must not be installed incorrectly.
Always check the bearing journal clearance (see
), before final assembly of the crankshaft. Failure to correctly select crankshaft bearings will result in severe engine damage.
Install and lubricate the crankshaft bearing shells with clean engine oil (see bearing selection on page
Lubricate the crankshaft journals with clean engine oil.
Position the lower crankcase to the upper. An assistant may be required to support the crankcase during alignment.
Fit the bolts into the lower crankcase and hand tighten until the bolt heads are near contact with the crankcase. Note the position of the hardened washers under bolts one to eight.
The crankcase bolts are tightened in stages.
Two different sizes of crankcase bolts are used. All bolts are tightened through the first stage of the tightening procedure but only the M8 size bolts are tightened at the second stage.
Failure to follow the correct bolt tightening sequence may result in permanent crankcase damage.
